At that time, the celestial son thought of his heavenly palace and returned to the heavens.
At that time, the non-Buddhist path of wrong views and BrÄhmans said:
'These lands are under the protection of such-and-such gods.'

They composed various treatises and praises. In this way, the non-Buddhist path of wrong views and BrÄhmans who resided in the forest, upon seeing this, revered and bowed their heads in respect, but only observed his appearance and gave rise to reverence and faith, not truly knowing that he was a celestial son of the second heaven.
They further gave rise to a view of discrimination, thinking:

'This celestial son travels everywhere, his body like a mass of fire. It is said that the people of JambudvÄ«pa enter the fire with their bodies. For this reason, they are reborn in a good destination and receive a heavenly body.'
The non-Buddhist heretics and brÄhmans then composed heretical treatises, either establishing their own tenets, or expounding their own causes and similes, or making praises.
Having themselves fallen into wrong views, they also taught others, causing them to accept and practice, burning their bodies with fire, hoping to be reborn in the heavens.
Thus, unable to truly see and know, they expounded wrong causes and effects, which are not real fruits and retributions. When the body perishes and life ends, they fall into hell.

Furthermore, the non-Buddhist heretics and brÄhmans who dwell in the forest give rise to wrong views.ğŸ”½Seeing this celestial son descend from the heavens towards JambudvÄ«pa, because of the distance, they see unclearly.

The brahmins living in the forest, upon seeing this, gave rise to their own discriminations, saying that the people of JambudvÄ«pa threw themselves off high cliffs, and because of this cause and condition, were reborn in the good destinies and received heavenly bodies.

Therefore, the brahmins of wrong views themselves threw themselves off high cliffs, wishing to seek rebirth in the heavens, and further used this method to teach others, composing false treatises or praises, speaking of this wrong Dharma as the fruits of karma.
Because of their wrong views, falsely speaking of cause and effect, when their bodies perished and their lives ended, they fell into the evil destinies and hells. This is called wrong view.

At that time, the brahmins of wrong views and non-Buddhist paths living in the forest saw this celestial son descend from the heavens towards JambudvÄ«pa. Giving rise to such false distinctions in this way, not seeing things as they really are, they create false theories, either establishing their own tenets, or stating their own reasons and examples, creating their own wrong views, and further teaching others to enter into wrong views.

Such Brahmins with wrong views bring no benefit to themselves, cause harm to others, and upon the dissolution of the body and the end of life, fall into a bad realm of existence and are reborn in hell.

Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil realms and are reborn in hells.

Non-Buddhists, seeing this, create false theories or praises, explaining wrong causes.
Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil realms and are reborn in hells.
In this way, they do not truly see the immeasurable, create false theories, do not truly see, deceive themselves, and do not truly see.

vainly giving rise to great regret.
The river of craving is vast, the five faculties are its ferry, this shore is terrifying, the other shore is peaceful.
Seeing it, one falsely understands, not knowing as it truly is, this person of wrong views falls into hell.
This person of wrong views, seeing non-causes as causes, falls into hell,
due to inverted views.
Foolish people are confused about cause and effect, bound by the prison of existence, and experience various sufferings.
The fruits and retributions of karma have birth and death, if one sees them as they truly are, one reaches the other shore.
Foolish people seek desires, deluded by desires, they fall into hell,
like moths to a flame.
Upholding precepts among humans, practicing right views, and attaining rebirth in the heavens, are not due to ascetic practices.
Engaging in wrong views, relying on wrong pride and knowledge, deceiving others,
and entering the great dark ocean of ignorance.
Suffering in the world is due to wrong views;
not by tormenting the body can one attain liberation.
The wise say to subdue the mind, burn the mountain of afflictions,
and then attain liberation.
Practicing right views, extinguishing all afflictions, seeing the true reality, and then attaining liberation.
All non-Buddhists confuse the world, without tranquility,
and no place for not lying.
The non-Buddhist teachings in the world are very deceptive, even if sought for a hundred eons, there is little truth.
The teachings of the world are all true, but worldly words are binding like poison.
With a loving mind, one creates merit and attains impermanent happiness, but the teachings of the world
attain permanent happiness.
Impure and evil, causes and conditions come together, and there are empty words, but no sincerity.
Thus, false words and deceptive people fall into the dark and frightening place.
' Thus, the bhiká¹£u truly saw and spoke this verse.
How do sentient beings attain true knowledge and true insight, and not give rise to wrong views?
Wrong views are themselves without true insight, and cause others to have wrong views.
Because of wrong views, one may either practice them oneself or explain them to others, falling into hell oneself and also causing others to fall into hell.

At that time, the celestial beings observed all JambudvÄ«pa, rode the celestial birds, returned to the Heaven of the Thirty-three, arrived at the celestial palace, and told the other celestial beings as before.
They again enjoyed games and pleasures in the gardens and forests, entertained themselves with music, and were fully endowed with various merits.

They enjoyed games and pleasures in all the places adorned with various jewels, until their delightful good karma was exhausted, and they ended their lives in the heavens, transmigrated according to their karma, and fell into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.

If reborn among humans, they always experience peace and happiness, are free from illness and affliction, are born in prosperous and peaceful countries, and receive a male body with complete faculties, becoming either a king or a great minister.
This is due to their remaining karma.
Next, the bhiká¹£us, knowing the fruits of karma, contemplated the abodes of the Thirty-three Celestials.
They saw with their wisdom of hearing:
The twenty-seventh ground of the Thirty-three Celestials is called Wisdom Practice.
What karma do sentient beings have to be reborn in that heaven?
He saw with his wisdom of hearing:

There are sentient beings who greatly uphold precepts, cultivate good karma, see the fruits of karma as they truly are, have faith and joy in their minds, always perform good karma, abandon unwholesome deeds, their minds are honest, stay away from bad friends, and do not even walk the same road with them, do not discuss with them, and do not live with them.
Such good karma is cultivated everywhere, like refining true gold.
In the present world, he is loved and respected by everyone because he cultivates goodness.

If there is a bhiká¹£u who always cultivates reading and reciting the sÅ«tras, the Vinaya, and the Abhidharma, such a bhiká¹£u diligently cultivates, whether during the day or night, without slacking off.

If it is dark at night and they stop studying, if there are sentient beings who respect the Buddha's teachings and these monks, and offer lamps to the Sangha, out of respect for the Dharma and respect for the Three Jewels, they also practice giving to increase the goodness of studying.
If it is very hot, they offer fans, so that there is no darkness or heat, and they hear the monks discussing the holy Dharma, and their minds are very joyful.

Because of the power of these two kinds of meritorious causes and conditions, these people of good karma benefit themselves and others. When their body perishes and their life ends, they are born in the heaven of the thirty-three celestials, the realm of wisdom practice.

Having been born in that heaven, because of their good karma, their bodies emit light surpassing the sunlight ten times over. They are worshipped by all the celestial beings. Surrounded and worshipped by countless hundreds of thousands of celestial maidens, all of whom are the celestial son's former close friends, they are cheerful and smiling, adorned in various ways.

Their bodies are sublime, with excellent features and majestic virtue, all adorned. Free from jealousy, they love and respect each other, never leaving each other's side for a moment, all giving rise to joy and intimacy with the celestial sons.
In their hands they hold lotus flowers, or golden flowers, or silver flowers, or vaiá¸Å«rya flowers, or sparÅ›a flowers, or various jeweled flowers.
If it is a golden lotus, the stem is made of white silver, and the pistils are made of red jewels;

At that time, the god, seeing the goddesses, his mind gave rise to joy, and his lustful mind became agitated. With an evil lustful mind, he rose from his seat, obtaining something unprecedented.
He went to the goddesses, leaping and rejoicing, all uniting in harmony to enjoy pleasures, singing, dancing, laughing, and playing, causing the god's lustful mind to increase.
In this way, the goddesses surrounded him and played in the garden grove.
The gods' garden groves have the radiance of many jewels, and all desires are fully present.

Under these trees, they play and enjoy pleasures. Various birds sing wonderful sounds, indistinguishable from the sounds of the goddesses. Adorned with desires, flowers and fruits are abundant. There are hundreds of thousands of flowing springs, lotus ponds, and rivers surrounding the garden grove.
In this way, the god plays and entertains with the goddesses, experiencing immeasurable pleasures, due to his good karma.
At that time, the god again went with the goddesses to another forest, enjoying music and entertainment, fulfilling their wishes, and experiencing heavenly pleasures.
The fruits of the precepts loved by the sages are accomplished and perfected.
In this way, the god, surrounded by goddesses, went to the forest of games called Manibhadra.

The old gods, seeing the god, all came out to welcome him, their hearts filled with joy, as if seeing close relatives and brothers. They comforted and greeted him, and together entered the forest, enjoying heavenly pleasures with the sounds of the five kinds of music.
In this way, the god experienced various pleasures, and again had immeasurable joy in the Manibhadra forest. His eyes saw various colors, and his heart was filled with joy.

The gardens and forests on the ground were all adorned with the seven treasures. Golden-colored jeweled garments adorned the forest trees, and in this way, various jeweled trees were used for adornment.
The ground is soft, and countless foods and drinks flow from the rivers. Looking at all these colors, the eyes are filled with joy.
In this way, the newly born celestial being enjoys pleasures with the celestial assembly.

The celestial being further goes to the lapis lazuli ground, and together with the celestial maidens, he sees the celestial garments born from the trees, their colors bright and pure, very lovely. A gentle breeze stirs them, moving with the wind, up and down, adorned with countless colored bees, their light like lamps.
The celestials, seeing this, give rise to a rare mind and great joy. Together with the celestial maidens, they go to this tree, making celestial music, playing and enjoying pleasures.
At this time, the celestials in this forest give rise to a rare mind in the flowers, and from within the flowers emerge celestial mÄtu, endowed with all the most wonderful flavors.

The heavenly beings had never seen such colors, smells, tastes, and textures before. Seeing them all gave rise to a hundred times more joy and pleasure, and they drank the heavenly wine of the finest taste.
The heavenly beings drank it and, together with the heavenly maidens, played and enjoyed themselves, singing various wonderful tunes and praising King Åšakra:
It is by the power of the causes and conditions of Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, that we are able to enjoy the five desires in this ManicÅ«á¸a Garden and Grove.

At that time, the heavenly beings, together with the heavenly maidens, filled bowls of beryl with the finest heavenly wine and encouraged each other to drink this heavenly wine.
These heavenly beings, when they were among humans, practiced generosity and upheld the precepts. Now they have attained such superior, wonderful, fragrant, and flavorful karmic rewards.
According to their past karmic actions, superior, middling, and inferior rewards arise, and they feel ashamed in their hearts.

The net of MÄtaá¹…ga's deluded snares, drinking until life ends,
Falling back into hell, the dragons are also like this.
If seen, touched, smelled, or tasted, it makes people's minds deluded and intoxicated,
Therefore, among all snares, the wise abandon it.
Seeing it, one gives rise to attachment; touching it, one then smells it;
Smelling it, the mind is greedy for the flavor; being attached to the flavor, one is harmed.
Among all bonds, none surpasses being greedy for flavors;
It destroys fame, reputation, appearance, and strength, because of being attached to flavors.
Being confused and disordered by being attached to flavors, the eyes are always dazed and intoxicated,
The mind becomes deluded, leading to stupidity and confusion, not knowing what is good or evil.
Disdained by women, sleeping and lying in filth,
Without any awareness, unable to move on one's own.
Alcohol can destroy one's reputation, surpassing the fear of death,
Just like drinking poison, or like a dead snare.
The harm of drinking alcohol has thirty-six faults,
Knowing these faults, one should quickly stay away from it.
A person of great family and wisdom, defiled by alcohol,
Disregarded by the crowd, like grass blown by the wind.
' Thus, although these heavenly birds are animals, they criticize the gods, not to mention other gods.
These heavenly sons drink heavenly flavors, with superior, middling, and inferior tastes, complete with color and fragrance, according to the seeds of their good karma and vows.

Having drunk, they again go to the forest of Dhara Hall. In this forest, they wish to play and hear various sounds, their minds filled with joy. Blue utpala flowers are used as head ornaments. The celestial sons and celestial maidens surround each other, playing happily, their minds always thinking of the golden-colored light of the Dhara forest hall.

Having enjoyed themselves, they again go to the forest of Megha-megha. Having arrived in the midst of the Megha-megha forest, they see hundreds of thousands of palaces adorned with celestial garlands.

At that time, the lord of the gods Shakra rode on the great white elephant Airavata, surrounded by celestial sons, celestial maidens, and retinue, his mind filled with joy, wishing to benefit the careless gods.

When the celestial assembly saw Shakra coming, they all came out to welcome him, all bowing their heads to the lord of the gods. In front of the lord of the gods, they produced various wonderful sounds, singing, dancing, playing, laughing, and joyfully shouting.

Right mindfulness is superior to wrong mindfulness, and good thoughts can destroy evil thoughts;
Light can destroy ignorance, and the bright day dispels the dark night;
The bright moon is superior to the dark moon, and one always attains victory in this way.
Wisdom knows true reality, surpassing the desires of wrong views,
The noble eightfold path can destroy all evil paths;
The TathÄgata's four forms of fearlessness can destroy all fears,
Recollection destroys forgetfulness, and wisdom can destroy ignorance;

Uprightness is supreme over flattery, and truth can destroy lies;
Auspiciousness can destroy inauspiciousness, and fire can burn all firewood;

The lion's mind is courageous and strong, surpassing all beasts;
Contentment is superior to desire, the wise ones say so.

Wisdom can subdue, the wise ones say so.
Many evil and wrong views, much false speech,
Thus among the non-Buddhists, the TathÄgata is the most superior.

This lion seat now, the wise ones should abide in it.'

At that time, the asuras, having heard what Åšakra, Lord of the Gods, said, did not grow any further, because they had heard the binding of true words, they diminished and did not increase, their appearance, strength, and valor did not grow.

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Gods, gave rise to a joyful mind and went to the place where Maá¹‡ibhadra resided. Riding on the great white elephant AirÄvaá¹‡a, he soared through the sky and roamed about, heading for the Maá¹‡ibhadra forest.

Åšakra, Lord of the Gods, together with the goddesses, with various musical sounds, singing and dancing, enjoyed entertainment and pleasures.

Although he has attained insight into the truths, he still enjoys sensual pleasures, always contemplating the cycle of birth and death of sentient beings.
Having contemplated thus, he neither became angry nor delighted, but observed that all pleasant feelings are impermanent, perishable, and disintegrating.
Having understood this, he contemplated in his mind:
The devas fall due to their own karma. Where do they go to experience the fruits of their own karma?
Blown by the wind of karma, they fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals, transmigrating and suffering without a companion.
All the devas and goddesses are like this, and will surely part.
Such karma greatly creates the implements of pleasure, mocking all foolish ordinary people.'
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, having contemplated this, spoke a verse, saying:
Just as clouds in the sky are blown by the wind,
Gathering and dispersing in an instant, so is birth and death.
From time to time, like the flowers of the masses, one sees people having birth and death,
Everything will be ground to dust, just as the past has already passed.
Thus, when good karma ripens, one will experience heavenly bliss,
But when the good time is exhausted, the blissful experience will also be lost.
Time is like a forest, when it grows, it is very lush,
But when the time has passed, everything falls down.
The gods are like the leaves of a tree, the tree is like the place of experiencing bliss,
Experiencing bliss will lead to falling, there is no permanent bliss.
Just as rain falls in summer, not staying in the sky,
All pleasures are also like this, passing away moment by moment, not staying for a moment.
It is like a peacock, when wind and clouds come, it makes a sound,
When the wind stops, the sound also ceases, the heavenly pleasures are also like this.
It is like dry wood placed in a fire,
Heavenly pleasures are also like this, burned by the fire of time.
Having been born, they return to extinction, having gone through hundreds of thousands of cycles,ğŸ”½Deceived by craving, yet without a sense of weariness.
Covered by the net of delusion and craving, none can escape,
Playing with the gods, experiencing the results of unwholesome actions.

' Thus, the Heavenly Emperor, out of pity for the gods, having spoken these verses, rode upon the great white elephant AirÄvaá¹‡a, surrounded by the heavenly multitudes playing various kinds of music, producing wonderful sounds, and returned to the Hall of Good Dharma.
Because he had won against the asuras, his mind was filled with joy. The gods respectfully arrived at the Hall of Good Dharma.

The gods who dwell in Maá¹‡ibhadra experience desires without weariness, enjoying forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile sensations, playing in the gardens and forests, until their delightful good karma is exhausted, and they fall from the heavens and return, following the cycle of karma, falling into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.

If reborn among humans, they are born into a great and noble family, experience the utmost bliss, are upright and extraordinary, born in the central country where the right Dharma is practiced, are greatly wealthy and prosperous, have complete offspring, have a long lifespan, have harmonious retinues, and are fully endowed with all worldly resources and enjoyments, loved and respected by all people, becoming either a great king or a great minister.
This is due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the abodes of the Thirty-three Celestials.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The Thirty-three Celestials have twenty-eight abodes, called 'Many Parts.'
What karma do sentient beings have to be born in those heavens?
They know with their wisdom of hearing:

There are sentient beings who cultivate wholesome actions, rectify their body, speech, and mind, are sincere and not deceitful, do not harm sentient beings, always practice wholesome thoughts, their mind is sincere, stay away from bad friends, befriend good friends, do not associate with bad friends, do not converse with them, do not live with them, and do not do things with them, always avoid bad people, and do not befriend those who befriend bad people.

Befriend the wise and good, listen to the true Dharma, contemplate after hearing it, and let the mind enter the Dharma - wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate. If there is wholesome Dharma, then embrace it; if unwholesome Dharma is known, then abandon it.

Correctly contemplate and subdue the mind, be neither greedy nor desirous, uphold the seven kinds of precepts, not violate even the slightest, and always be greatly afraid of even minor transgressions.
All wholesome actions are like refined true gold, pure and spotless.
Such a person does not kill, does not steal, gives in charity, cultivates blessings, and when seeing those who kill and harm, rescues them and sets them free.
How does one save those who are killed?

If there is a man who violates another's wife, is captured by the authorities, beaten with a loud drum, exits through the right gate, and is about to be executed, without rescue or protection, with no hope, sorrowful and worried, about to go to the charnel ground.
When taken to the execution place, such a good person ransoms them and sets them free.
And practices giving and cultivates various merits.
How does a good person practice meritorious deeds?
If the dwelling place of the Saá¹…gha is in a wilderness without water, suffering from thirst, such a good person may build a well or a pond for them.
If there is a pond or well that has collapsed or is full of small insects, they repair it for the Saá¹…gha and place the small insects in other water.
In this way, even the smallest creatures are not harmed.
If they filter water with a strainer, they return the water insects to the water.
This is called not killing living beings.
How does one not steal?
They do not take even a blade of grass with a thieving mind;
If in the wilderness there are various fruits and vegetables, they do not intentionally take what they suspect belongs to others, this is called not stealing.

This person practices all wholesome deeds, and when the body perishes and life ends, they are born in the good realms, in the heaven of the thirty-three celestials, in the place of the multitude of gods.
They are born through the right gate, on a seat of true gold, a seat of white silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, malachite, red lotus flower treasure,
a seat of blue indra jewel, great blue king jewel, and pearl. They are born in such a precious and adorned seat.
Having been born in the heavens, they think to themselves:
'By what karma did I come to be born here?'
They then recollect and know for themselves:
'In my past life, I made this wholesome karma, making offerings to the saá¹…gha.
Good karma is like a parent, a cool jewel that gives rise to heavenly bliss, and one will definitely experience happiness.
Having had this thought, the celestial being will then see the fruits of his own karma.
Having seen the fruits of karma, he praises good karma and denounces evil karma.
Remembering his past lives, he thinks of the ground of human karma, and the ground of immeasurable good karma is like a father and a mother.
At that time, the celestial being, having remembered his past lives, spoke a verse, saying:
By goodness one obtains a human body; having obtained it, one should not be negligent.
Create various good karmas, and because of this one can be reborn in the heavens.
A human body is extremely difficult to obtain; having obtained it, one may be negligent.
Confused by negligence, one will fall into hell upon death.
Create the three kinds of good karma and practice the seven kinds of precepts;
Destroy the three enemies and you will receive a heavenly body.
If a person subdues afflictions but has not yet severed the mind of craving,
This person, due to the causes and conditions of craving, will be reborn in the heavens.
Destroying jealousy, the den of great suffering,
Practicing various forms of giving, this person is reborn in the heavens.
Regarding others as one's own self, having compassion and protecting sentient beings,
Always taming the mind with a compassionate heart, this person is reborn in the heavens.
Regarding stealing as like fire, practicing giving to all,
Cultivating one's own mind, this person is reborn in the heavens.
Regarding others' wives as one's own mother, always contemplating the truth,
Not defiled by the mud of desire, this person is reborn in the heavens.
Fire arises from one's own mind, born from the drill of the tongue,
If one abstains from this false speech, one will be reborn in a good realm.
Harsh speech destroys the compassionate mind, the wise are able to abandon it,
Always delighting in speaking gentle words, one is born in the heavens.
Regarding frivolous speech as a knife, always staying far away from it,
